price.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money you have to pay for something
price.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Supermarkets often offer you two products for the price of one.
The price of fuel keeps going up.
We agreed a price for the bike.
price.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: something unpleasant that you must suffer in order to be successful, free etc, or that you suffer because of a mistake or bad action
price.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The awful boat journey was a small price to pay for freedom.
They may pay a high price for their few years of glory.
The country will pay a heavy price for the government’s failure.
She was finally made senior executive, but at what price!
He’s never at home, but that’s the price of success.
price.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: the amount of money you have to pay for something
price.translation[0].note_box[0].section: House prices in the UK are very high.
With such low prices, there are lots of eager buyers.
The price was reasonable for such good food.
I am sure we can agree on a fair price.
Many fans paid astronomical prices for their tickets.
£10,000 seemed an exorbitant price for the rug.
People seem willing to pay inflated prices for houses in central London.
A poor harvest led to higher food prices.
Did you get a good price for your car?
We sell quality cars at bargain prices.
The house is available at a knockdown price of $195,000.
We think the stock’s current market price is too high.
The property is worth more than the asking price.
You can obtain a loan for up to 90% of the purchase price.
Tax is 40% of the retail price of a typical bottle of wine.
When supplies go down, prices tend to go up.
In real terms, the price of clothes has fallen over the last ten years.
The price of oil soared in the 1970s.
Gas prices have continued to fluctuate in recent months.
Over 1,000 paintings will be shown with prices ranging from £50 to £5,000.
Manufacturers have had to put their prices up.
The company recently cut the price of its best-selling car.
Many carpet stores have slashed prices to bring in customers.
Publishers are not permitted to fix prices with one another.
Now all we need to do is agree on a price.
I paid a very reasonable price for my guitar.
Farmers now get a decent price for their crop.
I’m sure the painting would fetch a good price in London.
Consumers are facing more fuel price rises.
Holiday sales were down, even with drastic price cuts.
A price freeze on nine basic goods was announced on June 14.
Poor demand led to a sharp drop in prices.
The sharp rise in wholesale food prices will have to be passed onto customers.
Unfortunately, there was nothing in our price range.
price.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: something unpleasant that you must suffer in order to be successful, free etc, or that you suffer because of a mistake or bad action
price.translation[0].note_box[1].section: We paid a heavy price for our mistakes this season.
She won fame, but it came at a high price.
The success of the nation’s businesses has exacted a dreadful price from the people.
Smokers often pay a high price in terms of their health.
Any country breaking international law will be made to pay a heavy price.
The sport can exact a terrible price from its participants.
something is a small price to pay
Changing his job would be a small price to pay to keep his marriage intact.
price.translation[0].note_box[2].section: the amount of money that you have to pay for something
The prices in that shop are rather high.
You can have a two-course meal for a special price of £9.95.
the amount of money that you have to pay for services, activities, or things you need such as food and electricity
The cost of the two-day course is $1,295.
Many banks are raising their borrowing costs.
a sudden increase in energy costs
the amount of money that something is worth and that people are willing to pay if it is sold
The value of the painting was estimated at £500,000.
Fine wines may increase in value.
The shares have gone down in value.
price.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to decide the price of something that is for sale
price.translation[1].definitions[0].note: Price is usually passive in this meaning
price.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to put the price on goods to show how much they cost
price.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to compare the prices of things
price.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: We spent Saturday morning pricing microwaves.
price.translation[1].note_box[0].section: The clothes shops all seemed to be full of highly priced designer clothes.
The food was good and reasonably priced.
On the outskirts of many towns, you will find moderately priced motels.
Lower costs meant that Japanese exports remained competitively priced.
There are some very modestly priced artificial plants to be had.
These figurines are attractively priced at £32.
price.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money for which something is bought, sold, or offered
price.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: They agreed on a price of $10,000 for the car.
Some mines may close because of gold’s current low price.
The bonds continued to fall in price.
Buy one shirt and get a second at half price.
People today are attracted to discount stores because they don’t want to pay full price.
price.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: used to say that you can obtain something, but only if you pay a lot of money for it, or if the cost is very high in other unpleasant ways
price.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The track was designed to allow higher train speeds at a price, and that price was safety.
price.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: if you are prepared to do something at any price, you are determined to do it, even if it is very difficult and the cost is very high
price.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The government is prepared to hang onto power at any price.
Sorry, that painting’s not for sale, not at any price  (=no price could be high enough).
price.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: to say how much something costs, or to give something a financial value
price.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: The government hasn’t put a price on the stake it wants to sell.
price.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to fix the price of something that is for sale
price.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: If the stock is priced at about C$24 a share, it probably will be well received by the market.
She priced her T-shirts at $22 only to find a competitor moving faster at $20.
Today’s moderately priced clothes look almost as good as high priced designer clothes.
price.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to fix the price of bonds, shares etc
price.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The notes were priced to yield 6.88%.
Many commercial loans are priced off  (=in relation to) Fed funds, which currently are around 4%.
price.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: to compare the prices of things
price.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: We spent the morning pricing microwaves.
price.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: to put the price on goods, showing how much they cost
price.translation[3].definitions[4].defi: if you have been priced out of the market, you can no longer afford to buy something because prices have become too high
price.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: Younger people with jobs need homes but they have been priced out of the housing market.
price.translation[3].definitions[5].defi: to demand too much money for the goods or services you are offering, so that people are no longer willing to buy them
price.translation[3].definitions[5].exam: The hotels have priced themselves out of the market with typical cost at one chain of $100 to $120 a night compared with our average room cost of $50.
